author: Denise Recalde
title: Marie Osmond Willing To Sing At Trump's Inauguration
text:
Marie Osmond has stated she'd perform at President-elect Donald Trump's upcoming inauguration concert, if she was able to.
The 57-year-old had performed at previous inaugural ceremonies before, including Ronald Reagan's in 1981 with Donny Osmond, her brother. 
She cited the reasons of America needing to "unite" and "support our president whether we're happy or sad," Yahoo Finance reports. 
Marie added: "We should come together and I think an Inauguration should be a time to unite, it really should."
The singer is referring to the divisive national split between supporters of Hillary Clinton versus those of Donald Trump that arose as a result of the contentious November 2016 Presidential election.  
However, the singer-and-actress has since stated she will be on vacation during the upcoming inauguration and will not be able to perform for Trump. 
So far, several A-list stars who have been invited to perform at Trump's inaugural event have declined, including Sir Elton John, Andrea Bocelli, Moby, Celine Dion and most recently Rebecca Ferguson. 
Although Marie has not been invited to sing next week, The Beach Boys are reportedly still mulling whether or not to perform at the inaugural concert, The Daily Mail reports. 
A representative for the band said: "The Beach Boys have been asked to perform as part of the inauguration festivities. But no decision has been made at this point as to how or whether they will participate. We will let you know as soon as a decision is final."
Rebecca Ferguson stated on Jan. 10 that she had declined to participate at the ceremony for Trump, dropping a hint that she wasn't allowed to sing a song of her choice.
The 30-year-old UK singer had stated she would participate so long as she could sing the song Strange Fruit, a 1939 song originally sung by Billie Holiday.
The song's lyrics deal with racism in the 1930s in America and is based on an Abel Metropol poem. 
In a statement Ferguson said: "There are many grey areas about the offer for me to perform that I'm unable to share right now, but I will not be singing."
One of the very few names confirmed for next week's inauguration is Jackie Evancho, a runner up on America's Got Talent in 2010. 
She will be singing the national anthem.
